characters: INT. MILES DAVIS' MANHATTAN HOME- DAY
LIKE I KNEW THIS WAS GOING TO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Black. Then a frozen image - MILES DAVIS (DC), 29, full youthful glory, on stage on a soundstage, at the mic, in front of first great sextet, 1955, beautiful. The image begins to move, fast forward, whirs (stock), images blurring by to performance, many years later -

dialogues.speaker: CREDITS ROLL
dialogues.text: MILES DAVIS, 53, speaks in his cool rasp. You have to lea forward to hear. He really knows how to make you listen.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This one. Right here... The tape slows, plays at regular speed. DAVE BRADEN, 38, speaks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE BRADEN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Ok. Agartha...

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Osaka, Japan. - '75. "Prelude 2 Agharta" plays. Funky. Nasty. Gutbucket bass, guitar... SUPER: Prelude Fades up. Fades out... (NOTE: All SUPERS i the script are Miles Davis songs) ON STAGE: A trumpet player stands at the center, the hub quintet. Tilt up to reveal: MILES DAVIS, 48, adorned like psychedelic pimp-god. Hunched over, horn bell pointed at floor, soaked with sweat, his back to the audience, iconically Miles, searching for something buried in the music.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Funky...

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yep... Cut the sound down...

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Couple more minutes here guys.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No, other side, Nick. A GEAR BELLY wipes frame - PULL BACK FAST, 70s style, focus and refocus, revealing Davis, looking a little older, but clean as grandmom's chittlins. He sits in a chair while the interview is set- Miles holds a RED TRUMPET, a small mic attached to the be IN THE ROOM - He noodles on the horn, intermittently play with the music during the conversation. (Throughout the interview the camera plays a modal phrase, its attention between Miles here and the Miles there in Japan). IN JAPAN - Miles straightens, looks out into the crowd; w see FANS grooving to the rhythm reflected in HIS SHADES. POV: a dark void, flashbulbs, shadows, a crowd of unseen fans. He starts to play again but stops - for the first t in thirty years not knowing what to say. We see the momen from multiple angles and angels. From high up, Miles look small. Miles looks to the wings, searching... for someone among those standing around, and beyond... a face he cannot fin REVERSE ANGLE - POV of Miles from an empty void in the wi CAMERA moves a little. Alive... TWO SHOT - Miles here and in Japan. Japan Miles is sittin over ‘79 Miles’ angel shoulder, but no longer playing in ear.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: So, Miles, I know it’s always “go forward, go forward”, but even if just for context we have to get into (explore) your earlier stuff and modal jazz's influence -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I don't like that word; "jazz"

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Nope, I...

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (helping them to “get it”) That's a made up word. Tryin' to box somebody in. (get it) Don't call my music jazz.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Right. You refer to it as the music of the times....

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Social music.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Social music. Perfect. On TV, Miles mashes out an atonal chord with his right ha and cranks the volume louder and louder, silencing the ba As the din of the chord reverberates, recedes, he contemplates the trumpet’s bell, etched with a curvaceous scroll, his name in bold, flickering blue in the stage li

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (going quickly through the checkpoints) So Be-bop, boom. Gil, the Nonet thing... Then let’s dig in a little bit... Kind of Blue, So What, modality, of course, binary compositions and how that applies to life, your life, women and art, the boxing -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (obvious ) Right. Just not... “jazz.” Miles noodles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (to techy) We getting close?

dialogues.speaker: TECHY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Almost.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Cool. (to Miles) Ok, so I start; In seventy-five, one of the most prolific and influential artists in all of music, shockingly, stopped playing. Went silent, leaving the world -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Look, you're gonna tell it, don’t say it all corny and shit. On the TV screen, a surreal moment -- just the horn and M surrounded by mute musicians. Freeze frame.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, what would you say, Miles? Framed as it is, it looks like ‘75 Miles is waiting to h the answer too. Long beat as Miles thinks, composing in h head. Miles puts his horn to his lips. BAM-BAM-BAM! - GUNSHOTS tear into the aural landscape TAK

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MILES DAVIS' GREEN, (4 SEATER)
dialogues.text: SOUNDTRACK: "Aghartha" pumps up to full, 1970s Blaxploita shoot 'em up volume. The car ROARRRRRRING across a mostly deserted LOWER MANHA street in the midst of a GUNFIGHT BAM-BAM-BAM! MILES DAVIS, passenger, DAVE Braden, white, driver, a bla eye, fat lip, dry blood on his jacket, both dressed slick stylish, cool and ducking for cover - A BLACK LINCOLN TOWN CAR with blacked out windows TEARING after them - we don't see who's in there, just one GUN ou the driver's window blasting the Jaguar...BAM-BAM! Miles, Dave, crazy ADLIBING: "Fuck, shit, motherfuckers.. The Towncar is ultimately no match for the ROCKETING Jagu Dave wrestles the wheel, stick, pedals, on the job traini FISHTAILING the beast AROUND THE CORNER - Dave loses control - the Jaguar SKIDS toward the wall - A BULLET pierces the Jaguar's body - one SLAMS into MILES THIGH - (or ricochets off the sidewalk as Walter scramble out of his car and into Miles’ hip there) Miles HOWLS as the Jaguar spins, almost RAMS into the WAL a MEAT PACKING WAREHOUSE, before screeching to a stop; it stalls out. Dave can't start it. The Towncar's GUNNING ri for them -— Miles and Dave scramble out of the car, Miles clutches a BRIEFCASE, hobbling. Dave helps him -— Miles FIRING at the oncoming Towncar - It swerves, grindi to a halt by the Jaguar. WALTER, a serious looking black jumps out of the car - Miles and Dave, scramble INTO AN ALLEY, Miles tripping, dropping the briefcase, contents spilling out: A bunch of STAFF PAPER with musical notes scrawled on the fly away in the wind - plus A REEL TO REEL TAPE in a can rolls out... (labeled: 7-9-78).  Miles lurches for the tape, and at the storm of papers blowing around him - it all means everything to him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MILES DAVIS' MANHATTAN HOME- DAY
dialogues.text: LOW CRAZY ANGLE. Where are we. All is SILENT save for a guttural, soft, scratchy, scatting. The CAMERA MOVES alon the floor, discovering a COCKROACH, moving quickly, darti in and out of pockets of light, and over clutter, scatter debris, discarded food wrappers, searching for something clearly not found. A wad of paper crashes to the floor ne the bug, sending it scurrying off for cover. We TILT UP a pair of raggedy SLIPPERS, dark, ashen heels stuffed into them, up rusty CALVES, the back of a worn out CHAIR and u over the slumped shoulders of a man hunched there, HEADPH plastered on his ears, a pair of wrinkled, charcoal hands jammed tightly over them. A REEL TO REEL tape machine spo out unheard music. 7-9-78 written on the label.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Duh - duh - da - dee - da - Da - dee - da - We PAN finding Miles framed like a never before seen icon photo of the cool; his ebony skin challenging the darknes his surroundings - he's a stunning sight. His chiseled features softened by shadow, his lithesome form draped in pale silks. In an instant, his spidery fingers run tender circles around the perimeters of his scatting lips, like memory of lost, but not forgotten love, then to a nearby of STAFF PAPER. Miles scrawls, jotting hieroglyphics, the encrypted language of the papers just seen blowing in the wind...

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Da - dada - dee - dumdum - da - A DISTANT ANGLE. Dark. Steamy sunlight begs at the hems o drawn curtains. A former church. Little recollection of religion in the ghostly curves of the place. Now it feels haunted. Weeks, months of clothes strewn about, dirty dis empty Heineken and cognac bottles, magazines, newspapers grime carpet the floor, spiders perched in spiderwebs. Drips of errant flickering light from a TV OFF-SCREEN pla with the corners of the frame. On the silent screen, GRAI STOCK FOOTAGE of boxer JACK JOHNSON, July 4, 1910, the "F of the Century" against Great White Hope JAMES J. JEFFRIE before 20,000 people in Reno. In the 15th round Johnson knocks Jeffries down, and the nearly all white crowd jeer spitting rage...  We gather details of a lusciously frayed, once elegant tricked out pad of animal skins, Lucite and leather. PHOTOS on the wall shelves, on top of the piano, of Miles with everyone who's anyone, playing everywhere on the pla The world-beater. A sign says: "No Visitors"

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Da - datdat - dedaw - dat - dat Miles sits riveted, eyes squeezed shut, 7-9-78 coming thr the headphones, as he scrawls on the pad, like a physicis trying to work out The Theory of Everything. Miles’ face contorts as a sudden pain shoots through his hip. He reac for it, his arm in the headphone cable, inadvertently pul it from the machine and letting in an almost painful

dialogues.speaker: CACOPHONY OF SOUNDS
dialogues.text: STREET NOISES; car HORNS, shouting, other people’s shitty music, etc. A TEA KETTLE on the KITCHEN STOVE WHISTLING for all its worth... The PHONE RINGING and RINGING... INCESSANT KNOCKING ON THE FRONT DOOR... ON THE RADIO: Miles Davis, "So What" from "Kind of Blue". Miles sits in the midst of it all for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ...fuck... Miles takes the headphones off, his concentration blown. stuffs them into the table DRAWER the reel to reel machin sits on. The drawer sticks and Miles battles with the bro thing, frustration ultimately winning, and leaves it half shut. This writing session is over. Miles' eyes adjust to the light, peek up, like flickering embers - stare at his TRUMPET on it's stand, shimmering b beneath the dust, like a glimmer of life, staring at him, challenging him to pick it up and play.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: 'Fuck you looking at? As to a wife in a marriage that has climbed downward from love, to war, to neglect. In an instant, and unresolved. Miles painfully stands and we almost hear the creeks of living. He squints hard as he turns to go into the kitche pivoting on his ruined hip. When Miles opens his eyes he FRANCES TAYLOR, early 30s, staring at him, perfection in chocolate, uncorrupted by the decay around her, with an a of where you want to be. She glides by locking him in her gaze, an enigmatic look on her face. Miles straightens up, locks into her eyes. He starts to s but Frances almost imperceptibly shakes her head, “no,” a walks on, HER LEGS, forever, and ever, as she turns and g up the staircase especially designed for this singular perfect view, and disappears into the BEDROOM, Gone from sight. Miles nods, picks up a half empty Heineken off the table tugs it back on the move, navigating through shadows thro by the cracks of light. Lays the empty beer bottle down o table with others. Passing, ignoring the RINGING PHONE... Passing, ignoring his own sounds on the RADIO Passing, ignoring the KNOCKING ON THE DOOR... Passing the TV - throwing a stiff right hook into the air unison with Jack Johnson, who knocks Jeffries down for a second time... INTO THE KITCHEN...stove on, pours green tea into a cup - sips, soothes his throat, lights a cigarette. After a lon drag Miles focuses in on the blue flame of the stove burn He’s captivated by the significance of the vision, if onl for himself. The FRONT DOOR KNOCKING STOPS and the cessation of this s snaps Miles out of it. He crosses back to the living room TAPPING ON THE WINDOW now, Miles ignores it; through a CR IN THE CURTAIN, we see the face of a pissed off Dave Braden... Finally, Miles has had it, and Miles picks up the RINGING

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (into the phone) What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (thick Kingston accent) Ah, you dere, huh, bumbaclot? You gonna make me hurt you, man.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Oh, is that right? (yells at the window) Get the fuck away from my window. Dave pops his head back out, leaving his post, disappears

dialogues.speaker: KINGSTON MACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Don’t play ‘round with your life, junkie. I fronted you product. You know what that means.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Fuck you, Mack. Get in line.

dialogues.speaker: KINGSTON, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You show your junkie face in any my spots and - Miles hangs up. ON THE RADIO, "So What" ends - DJ PHIL SCHAAP comes on, rapping in the background:

dialogues.speaker: SCHAAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Phil Schaap with you on KCWC-FM, New York, with the Miles Davis Marathon. That was the seminal "So What", from "Kind of Blue", 1959. That's the one in the time capsule, folks. The one they'll be talking about in a thousand years. The one you save from a burning building. The culmination. The mountaintop... Miles looks at the stereo SPEAKER, doesn't like what Scha saying. Miles pulls some reading glasses out of a little drawer filled with the things and grabs a YELLOW PAGES off the floor. He lights a cigarette, rips through the book until finds a number,. THE PHONE RINGS. Miles picks it up -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (on phone) Hello, is this Mi -  Miles hangs it up, picks it up again and dials. While it rings on the other end, Miles runs his finger over some cocaine residue on the table, and brushes his upper gums.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If you're out there listening, Miles, we miss you, the world misses you. Five years is just too long. Please, come back.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: It's Miles Davis... Yeah, really. Put that motherfucker Schaap on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAAP, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: After Miles put his stamp on this new music, the modal form, he went on to -- (beat, stunned) Really? Oh, my goodness, this is incredible... Folks, I believe we have the Miles Davis on the line. (picks up the phone/on air) Mr. Davis, is this really you?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Yeah, it’s me.

dialogues.speaker: SCHAAP
dialogues.text: My goodness. What an honor. This is-

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You talk too damn much. A time capsule is for old shit, dead shit. And I missed on "Kind of Blue".

dialogues.speaker: SCHAAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Missed? But Mr. Davis, I think most people would say it's a masterpiece. How exactly did you miss?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: This ain’t a interview. I'm a tough guy and I know tougher guys. If you tape this, I'll kill you. You got that?  10

dialogues.speaker: SCHAAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes sir, I got that.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Good. Now, forget it. (shift) And throw on some of that Sketches of Spain for me. Miles hangs up the phone. Sips more tea, fleetingly butts his cigarette in an overflowing ashtray, lights another o Dave Braden reappears, starts KNOCKING ON THE WINDOW agai Miles ignores him, goes to an EASEL with an in-process, w OIL PAINTING of a lush, mostly red and black, Picasso-esq woman in the stands of a bullfight, a dark-skinned matado stands in the ring. He stops, steps back, picks up the paint brush, dips it i color, adds a couple strokes to the work, studies it for few moments...

dialogues.speaker: SCHAAP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This one’s for you, Mr. Davis. Concierto De Aranjuez (Adagio), from Sketches of Spain... As "Concierto De Aranjuez (Adagio)", the romantic, epic m of battle...comes on the radio... A muffled conversation in front of his door pulls Miles' attention then - PHUMP -today's mail comes through the sl landing on a pile of weeks of unopened mail. Miles walks to the mail and with his bare foot sifts through today's arrivals. Dave starts knocking again, creaks open the mail slot.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Mr. Davis. If you could just open the door for a moment... Miles doesn't find what he's looking for. A storm cloud f around him. Miles walks over to the phone, dials. On the other end, George Butler's secretary answers:

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE'S SECRETARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: George Butler's office.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: It’s Miles.  11

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE'S SECRETARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. Hold a moment. A few moments later, HEAR GEORGE on the other end answer. He's solicitous, respectful. But this an old conversation

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey, how are -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: My money didn't come today.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello, Miles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Where's my check? $20,000.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (careful but firm) Where is the session tape?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You trying to piss me off?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (sighs) Of course not, Miles, but we've been over this; we can't release more money —

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Same shit -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: - until Columbia gets that new music.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: George-

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I know there's gold on that tape, Miles. $20,000 is chump change compared to the business we’re going to do. Miles fumes silently.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on, man, let's do it. Let's put our heads together and really start working on that comeback.  12

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I didn't go nowhere, George. Now you want some music, send me my money. Miles slams the phone down. Dave starts knocking again as “SKETCHES OF SPAIN" swells. Miles crosses tears open the with the chain on, his jaw seriously working his chewing Dave Braden stands there dressed differently than in the opening shoot out. No style: tweed, corduroy, loosened ti drops of red on his shirt, fresh scrape on his cheek, reddening around his eye. Dave's wearing some kind of sto that he's in the middle of.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Mr. Davis, hello. Really sorry to bother you but, I’m Dave Braden, Rolling Stone Magazine? Miles shuts the door - Dave sticks his foot in, preventin the door from closing. Miles' look - are you crazy?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Waitaminute...I'm here to do your comeback story. Wrong word. Miles expression changes. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Okay. The door closes. Dave straightens up, tucks in, slicks ba his hair, trying to appear half-way presentable. Miles flings the door open and - POW - clocks Dave in the face, Dave stumbles back -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What the - ? - recovers, fending Miles off. He blocks another punch - grabs hold of Miles shoving both of them into a crazy dos doe, and suddenly: Miles is OUTSIDE, barefoot, while Dave is INSIDE. Dave sl the door in Mile's face. INTERCUT: MILES OUTSIDE, DAVE INSIDE - Miles pounds on th door.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Open the door!  13

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Take it easy!

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Open it! Dave backs away from the door, takes the opportunity to w up the three steps, push open the saloon doors and peer i the room. ANGLE: PANS TO tape on the reel to reel, painting, boxing the TV, the ruinous decadent decay, evidence of empty coc bindles and residue; not what he was expecting. Dave pull out a small pocket camera (Agfa Optima 535); flash, flash flash... Stows that then produces a TAPE RECORDER, pushes RECORD.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (on hush, quick) Inside the master’s disheveled lair, the rumors now reality, jazz's Howard Hughes reviled and revealed -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Open the goddamned door! Dave stows his works, comes back to the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Alright. No more punching, man. Dave opens the door and Miles charges in, his hip aching, coming at Dave -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Get the fuck outta my house. Hands up, Dave back-peddles, defensively away from Miles deeper into room...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Calm down, Mr. Davis, please. I'm -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: That's the wrong way! Miles goes to a nearby drawer and retrieves gets his .38 special.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Shit, hold it... I... It's a job -  14 Dave trips back over a table, falls to the ground - as Mi arrives over him, and Dave blurts it out like a safe word

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Columbia! Your record company set it up! Miles stops -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yes. I’m just a writer, man. After a scary moment -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Can you drive, motherfucker? SUPER: Splash Fades up. Fades out... INT. MILES’ JAGUAR/EXT. MILES’ MANHATTAN HOME- A MINUTE L Dave is in the driver’s seat, checking out the freshest reddening “mouse” under his eye in the rearview mirror -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Prick... The front door of the house opens - Miles peeks out ginge into the sun, then exits, now wearing a dope brocade robe silk scarf and sunglasses, looking around, paranoid -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Open the damn door. - as he hobbles down the stairs to the car - Dave reaches across the console and pops open the passenger door for Miles, who gets in. Clocks Dave’s running tape recorder o the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the fuck is that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You mind?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Take that thing off my goddamned dash or I’m gonna slap you in the mouth with it.  15 Dave starts to comeback on Miles but bites his tongue, co out like something between a cough and a laugh. He pocket the thing, but not before he depresses RECORD. And Miles already scouring the car's interior for cocaine - glove compartment, map pocket, finding nothing but empty BINDLE which he crumbles up and tosses. Dave clocks the behavior Miles looks at him -

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's go. Dave works the ignition but it’s not turning over.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Pump it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know how to... The car grumbles to life - ENGINE ROARS - the 5/4, 6/4 br kinetic freedom of "Splash" on the SOUNDTRACK, and they p away from the curb just as an MG with 2 people inside, JA 25, black, and DIETER, 50, white, pulls up right where th were. Dieter opens the door and stands. Janice hops out, to the front of the car, calls out.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Miles! Miles and Dave don't hear or see Janice and Dieter. Dave studies Miles for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: So, where're we going? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Look, maybe we got off on the wrong foot. I just need to get a little background -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I gotta do your homework for you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Well, I could write some bullshit I got out of some...magazine. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it'd be nice to hear it in your own words, you know?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Miles Davis story. My words.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: That would be great.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Ok. I was born... went to New York, met some cats, made some music, did some dope, made some more music... ...then you came to my house. Take a left.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (beat) That's it?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Great. Guess I'll fill in the blanks later.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: It's what all you motherfuckers do anyway. Miles points. Dave turns left -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave parks in front of the Columbia Records Building. Mil snatches the keys out of the ignition, gets out. Dave isn moving -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I'll wait down here.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Get the fuck out of my car. Clear enough. Dave opens the door -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles storms in with disheveled Dave, breaking up the meeting.  17 Photos of Miles performing, and with George, populate the office. All eyes turn to the duo. GEORGE BUTLER, 48, blac soft-spoken style, stands up behind a large desk. In front of George’s desk, 2 WHITE EXECUTIVES, 40s, sit i chairs. In a 3rd chair off to the side is another white e well dressed and coiffed, KEN SCHWINN, 30.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Miles -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Don’t send people to my house. Write some dumb, fucking article... Write a check, George. George's secretary, outside the office, looks in at Georg shrugs, "sorry" - George waves her off, "it's okay" - she returns to her desk. Sitting on the couch behind Miles and Dave (and unnoticed them) is a slender man, white, sharply tailored, a touch the royal slick: HARPER HAMILTON, 35, his right hand man, Walter, and JUNIOR, 22, thin, black, good looking, jitter jonesing, a little sweaty, but sharp, if a bit wrinkled. trumpet case at his feet. When Junior sees Miles, he perk up, his idol right in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Wait a second, Miles, I - Miles pushes Dave over toward George, Dave jerks his arm away, handled enough for one day.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Take your boy back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I didn't send anybody to your house, Miles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Ok, guys -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You send this motherfucker to my house to write some comeback story?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I've never laid eyes on this guy.  18 Miles slow burns Dave.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Dave Braden. George is waiting impatiently -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: --- Rolling Stone Magazine. George buzzes his secretary -

dialogues.speaker: SECRETARY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (to his secretary) Get me Jann Wenner at Rolling Stone, please.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Um, I'm not sure Jann, himself, actually knows I'm here.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And why is that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Look, a source here at Columbia, not saying who, told me about Miles’ session and that you guys were probably already long lead planning for the whole, you know, comeback, promotional thing and - Dave peters out. It sits there like a log for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Man, you see this? This is the bullshit that happens when y’all start -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Miles -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Can I say something -

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You can get out -  19

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I do a session ya'll already got it out over the wire.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: In fairness, that was almost a year ago —

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: So what?! Can't wait to saddle me up again, huh? The fuckin' comeback.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Call it whatever you -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: There is no Columbia without me. How many records I cut for you, George? And I can’t take some time off?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course you can. And you have. And now you have new material and we're all incredibly excited to -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: My material, man, my tape. And if I don’t wanna give it to you - Ken, a take charge guy, puts up his hand, nods at George

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Guys, guys, can I get in here a sec...? Miles snaps a look.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (a warning) Ken...

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: S'okay. I got it. Ken Schwinn, A&R. Now, Miles, as you know, you're under contract here, and we paid for that recording session, so we actually own that tape and whatever music is it. Legally. And I don't mean this as a threat but - and George, back me up here -  20

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Miles! BAM - GUNSHOT! the LAMP right next Ken's head shatters. K yelps, ducks. Miles stands still, .38 smoking in his hand. Dave's looki at Miles, sort of "holy shit" impressed. Ken and the othe white guys are cowering.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You own my music? You must be a rich man, then. How much money you got?

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: What? George's Secretary runs to the door flushed. George holds a staying hand, freezing her. Miles walks up to Ken.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: On you. Right now. How much?

dialogues.speaker: KEN
dialogues.text: Uh, uh...I...uh...4-5 hundred -—

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You know what they say in Missouri? Show me! Ken takes out a gold money clip, Miles grabs it, tests it heft, turns to George -

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You ‘bout nineteen thousand light, but that's a start. - stuffs it into his jacket pocket. Harper stands, impres laughing, clapping.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Oh, man. Check that motherfucker, Mr. Davis. I love that. Miles swings around, business end gun not exactly pointed Harper, but close enough - Walter reaches like he might h a piece too, but Harper stops him -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (nice) Hey, hey... be nice... Walter relaxes. Harper reaches out to shake Miles' hand.  21

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harper Hamilton... Miles and Harper eye to eye. Game recognizing Game.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What an honor, sir. If I may, I'ma producer, working with this kid - He points to Junior.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's Junior... Miles looks sideways at the kid, Junior’s gaze, semi-defi looking back, trying to be cool. Harper cocks his head, nonchalantly plays air trumpet -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Scary. He’s playing a late set at the Vanguard tomorrow night. Love it if you’d be my honored guest...label mate. (drops the bomb, gesturing to George) We’re working out a deal here, too. Miles looks at George. Judas. George shrugs, "What do you want from me? It's business." Miles shakes his head, just been replaced. Harper goes on.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're a fight fan, right? Harper reaches back toward Walter, snaps - Walter puts tw passes in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I got a boxer on the card at the Cathedral tomorrow night. Maybe you'd like to check that out too, we can talk a little shop... Harper holds out the passes to Miles. Beat. We hear Dave' tape recorder CLICK off in his pocket and all eyes turn t him. Miles sticks out his hand. Dave sheepishly reaches i his pocket and turns the tape recorder over to Miles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: And I'm the asshole in the room, right?  11 22 Miles chucks the tape recorder into the waste basket, and walks out, Junior watching his every step.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (calling after) Miles... (to Dave) You. Let's go... George grabs Dave's arm, starts escorting him out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hold it, hold it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave pulls away. Harper watches, out of focus in the offi BG.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Waitaminute, Mr. Butler! Listen, listen... (steps up close) I get you that tape, me and you can do some business? George starts to answer then stops himself. He gives Dave hard look but doesn't say "no." And in that space -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Got it. Don’t say another word. (he turns to the receptionist) Stairs! The receptionist points. Dave flies off toward a door, knocking past a worker. Harper's made his way to the doorway, leans on the jamb -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Man. What a waste. He's probably more profitable dead than alive now, huh? George out of focus in the foreground. 11  23

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles sits back against the rail - what these muthufuckas just made him do. His hip now. Dull persistent ache. Can' escape himself - his music: the be-bop, uptempo "Tempus Fugit" mocks him from the speakers as a collage of Columb covers/artists silently study him. Chief among them is Frances, again - on the cover of "Someday My Prince Will Come". He wants to look at her, but doesn't, won't...but she's looking at him. Miles pushes at the back wall of th elevator and it rolls back on casters opening onto -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small group playing on stage, seen from the wings. The CAMERA moves around the band members - winds, brass, drum the pianist and eventually comes around finding Miles Dav 18 years younger, stepping up to the mic, center stage, killing it in this intimate venue. Watch him blow. SUPER: Tempus Fugit Fades up. Fades out...

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. CONVERTIBLE CAR
dialogues.text: Buddy, 30s, drives. Pretty NORA, black, 20s, up front wit Buddy. Miles, stylish, hair done in a marcel process, is back with his beauty, AVA, 20s, white. Miles is high, you see that shit in his eyes. Laughs and good times all arou Ava stands, arms raised, all sexy abandon, starts screami as loud as she can. Miles pulls Ava back down, rubber nec for cops. Zoom... EXT. FRANCES’ HOUSE - NIGHT Buddy pulls over to the curb, parks.

dialogues.speaker: BUDDY
dialogues.text: Gotta give this little bird a thing for my friend. Be right back. Gets a Tiffany's box from the glovebox. Buddy exits the c crosses the road to a small APARTMENT BUILDING, open air, California-style, rings the buzzer. Miles' attention is snatched away from Ava as Frances app at the top of the landing of her building. She walks down stairs - those legs. The first time he's laid eyes on her Takes his breath away.  24 As Ava and Nora talk, Miles gets out of the car, leans on lights up a cigarette. Buddy and Frances greet, he gives her the Tiffany's box, she's pleased, thanks him, they chat a minute, but her ey find Miles across the street, and they lock in a forever moment sealing their future. Miles turns back to the car, masking the following: Miles dips into his pocket, comes light, only a couple singles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (smiles) Ava, Let me hold Mr. Jackson.

dialogues.speaker: AVA
dialogues.text: (giggles) Sure, Miles... Ava hands Miles a $20 bill.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: And, hand me that pen. Ava reaches into her purse, hands Miles her pen. He drops cigarette, grinds it out as he strides across the street. Buddy turns to walk back, Miles passes him and steps up t Frances.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Miles Davis.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I know. - Frances Taylor. Miles pulls out the $20, writes his details on it, holds out.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Now you don't have to stare. Frances smiles, shrugs, let’s him just hang for a beat be eventually taking the bill. Miles smiles, turns, walking to the car cool as shit. Somewhere a phone rings.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (soft, smoky) Come watch me dance, Miles.  25 INT. NYC THEATRE/GRAND THEATRE — DAY Miles steps into the shadows of the wings, smoking a cigarette, digging the PORGY AND BESS rehearsal; for him all about the lead dancer: Frances. Standing by Miles is his close friend and arranger, GIL EVANS, 40s - white, rail thin, a natty argyle style, contrasting Miles' finely tailored Italian suit. Frances is playing Bess - lusty, steamy in her moves. She inspires Miles, she seems to be looking right at him, dan just for him - it's all over his face, he's falling in lo His inspired eyes drift to the TRIO; he ZOOMS IN ON the p keys, the ways the musician moves, collecting, co-opting and then back to FRANCES, the key to it all -- dancing a pas-de-deux with the chiseled, handsome LEAD DANCER; Mile clouds over. Fran stops the music with a wave of her hand.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Hang on. Let’s do that last section again. From the diminuendo?

dialogues.speaker: CHOREOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: Sure. Frances cues the pianist, they begin again. Miles clocks a couple white men (producers/financiers) , looking, in Miles’ mind, at Frances like he does - with desire; he's suddenly jealous knowing the men can see up skirt as it flies and flutters around her. Miles looks threatened, angry, his gut turning, surprised his reactions, all new for him, this obsessive desire to possess a woman. Frances spies Miles in the wings, and locks in, relishing power over him. She purposefully pushes away from her par and pirouettes in Miles’ direction, using him as her spot Almost there, she trips... Miles grabs for Frances, but BEFORE he catches her -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave surfing/tripping down the stairs, “completes” France fall but now in ‘79. Dave hits the landing hard.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Ow. Shit -  26 He scrambles to his feet, continues limping, down the fli of stairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles exits the elevator as Dave emerges from the stairwe trailing Miles through the lobby and eventually outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave bolts from the building, gets to the car as Miles ge in, the Jag a little boxed in by parked cars -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, I got you, it's cool, I'll drive. Miles shuts his door. Dave talks through the closed windo

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I should've told you what was up right off - Miles sticks the key in the ignition, cranks it but the ignition won’t turn over -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look, I understand where you're coming from with those guys up there - The car finally roars to life and Miles put it in reverse preparing to pull out. Dave rushes in front of the car, making his case through the windshield.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - it's never enough, right! They just suck you dry and fuck you over!

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. JAGUAR
dialogues.text: Miles looks back to check behind him, the turn itself hur - that hip's a bitch today -- and no medicine yet - fuck! Dave clocks it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Listen, listen, listen, listen - Sidling up.  27

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: - fuck the interview, okay? Let's get right. I know what you need, man. Let me get you right! Miles looks at him sideways, eases off the gas a bit.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (mouthing big) I probably shouldn't shout this next part. Dave gambles, creeps around to the drivers side, motions Miles to crack his window --

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know a guy, gets it like, whooo, from the root, it's good, not stepped on, we can go right now. Beat. They stare at each other. Then Miles gets out of th car. Dave steps back, makes space for this pissed off man with a gun.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You're a crazy, white motherfucker, you know that?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. Miles crosses around the Jaguar, gets in the passenger se Daves looks in at him -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So...? Dave gestures toward the driver's seat.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You waitin' for me to put a hankie down? Dave slides behind the wheel -

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. MILES' JAGUAR STATIC
dialogues.text: Miles watches the street for a beat then -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Where we going?  28

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Columbia.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: We just left Columbia, muthafucka.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: The other one, muthafucka. They drive off into traffic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave and Miles Drive up in the Jaguar right in front of a dorm building, in the red zone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Getting out of the car - Miles looking around like, “real

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (trust me) Really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave holds the dorm building door open for Miles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I did a story on this kid’s father. Big shot doctor who... crazy shit, doesn’t matter. Anyway, the rich little fucker's got the goods... Miles follows Dave -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At a dorm room door down the hall now.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: How much you holding?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Whatever’s in that clip.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Alright, just follow my lead.  29 Miles scoffs. Dave knocks on a dorm room door. The only reaction to Dave’s knocking is the volume on the music go up. Is that the sound of fucking under the music? Dave raps harder. Miles’ got that look on - ‘shit better here or you’re dead.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (0.8.)
dialogues.text: Later. Dave really bangs on the door, when finally it opens -

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What the - Revealing an exasperated and slightly out of breath 22-ye old skinny white kid, boxer shorts, severe bed-head: A ja plays on the stereo. A bong and weed on the table, the ki wasn't expecting company.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (especially this company -— in fact the last person he’d expect to see) No, uh-uh —

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Justin, wait - Justin goes to close the door, but Dave leans in - stalem

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Who the fuck are you to show up at my - you know what “off the record” means, asshole? Justin tries to close the door, Dave holds it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Aw, c’mon man, you knew what was up with that. You wanted to burn your old man and I helped. So what -

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: So what?!

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (enough) Get on with it, man. That signature voice draws Justin’s attention. It takes a second to register but when it does, a “holy fuck... Is t Miles Davis?” look spreads across Justin’s face.  30

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (that’s right) Uh huh. Dave pushes the door open revealing Miles Davis to Justin Dave and and Miles enter.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, I’m... Come in. They already are in but Justin is a little stunned with o of his idols in front of him. Dave closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside, a naked blonde co-ed, TAMI, is on the bed, coveri herself with a sheet. She's real cute. Look around the room, state of the art, daddy paid for st system - kind of a loungy pad, old leather couch, couple books strewn about, signed posters on the wall; Coltrane, Jimmy Page, James Brown. Justin can’t take his eyes off Miles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Let's do this quick. (off Tami) We don’t want to take up too much of your time.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: C'mere a second, man - But it’s Justin who moves in close to Dave - authoritativ and star-struck at the same time -

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What is going on? Why is he with you, I mean, why are you with him. What do you -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey, genius... Dave stares at him, waiting for the nickle to drop. Justi looks to Miles, back to Dave, gets it.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Oooohhhh, right. Yeah, yeah, yeah -— Justin moves to and opens a locked drawer, a scale and cocaine inside.  31

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, what can I do you for?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Make it an ei--

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: - a quarter. Dave shoots Miles a look. Miles just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Quarter. Yes, sir. When Justin scoots off to the stash, Miles pats his pocke the .38 nestled inside. “This can go another way too, you know." Dave tries to keep cool, but this is fucked up. Mi sniffs deeply, clears the pipes as Justin weighs out the dope. He ain’t leaving with a flake less than 7 grams. Justin’s oblivious.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know who the fuck this is, Tami? Tami half shrugs. Justin’s words come out in an excited w

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wow. What a fucking honor. I have a bunch of your -- (points across the room) -- and not just yours -- I mean, the whole, you know... original experience. Blues, gospel... Black music is where it’s at. Justin looks Miles up and down, seemingly really seeing h in his dishevelled state for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You... want to sit down, Mr. Davis? In Miles eyes, “fuck you and your pity” - but he covers.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Yeah. Scoot over, Tami. Dave chuckles. Tami grins, scoots over, pats the mattress next to her. Justin smiles, shakes his head -

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Alright. Justin holds out the bag of coke to Miles -  32

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's eight-hundred even. Miles tosses Justin the short clip. Dave goes in:

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Whoa, whoa, whoa, what?! Yeah, it’s $600 any other day I don’t come in here with him, right?!

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: What are you talking -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: (to Dave) Whoa, whoa, whoa? C’mere, man! Justin goes over close to Dave again. Less sycophantic.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: First you fuck me and now you’re gonna fuck me? Dave talks loud.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Forget this kid, Miles. He's a crook. You’re a crook, Justin.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Fuck you - (makes his case to Miles) - this is the price, Mr. Davis.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You've got to be joking - Dave goes over to Justin’s extensive record collection, a pulls out one classic Miles record after another, naming DAVE (CONT’D) Look at this... Birth of the Cool, Porgy and Bess, Sketches of Spain, Kind of Blue-- Jesus, you got a whole lifetime of this man’s stuff and you're shystering him -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (playing along) Which one does he play, Tami?  33 Tami hums "So What” the famous first two notes in Miles’ canon.

dialogues.speaker: TAMI
dialogues.text: Doo-do

dialogues.speaker: TAMI, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He plays that one a lot - that one too. I like that one. Miles walks over to the collection, has a look for himsel finds “Someday MPWC”, pulls it out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Of course you do.

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Listen, I’m not shystering you, Mr. Davis. Look - (counts the cash, peels off a couple bills, puts them on the table) - This is fine. I’1l give you an eighth.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Man, you're still stupid... Dave picks up the albums.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .--"give” him an eighth. Go get me a fucking pen. Dave hits the right note. Justin pricks up. This is gold. Dave glances at Miles who smiles slightly Dave's solo (Coltrane), both of them playing this kid now. Miles then turns, dead serious.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Just do a couple, Miles...

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Um um.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Right. Sorry. I was thinking... Forget it. That was stupid. Let’s go. Dave plops the records down.  34

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Wait, w-w-waitwaitwait...just hold on. Listen...I - I’m sorry - (in tight to Miles, confession) Look, I’d go ape-shit if you would sign a couple of these for me. You do that, it’1l cover what you're short. Justin finds a pen, holds it out to Miles -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: For the quarter, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, for the quarter, what do you think I’m saying, jerk? Miles “reluctantly” takes the pen. Justin grabs the recor hands them to Miles with reverence. As he signs, Miles looks at the iconic record covers for moment. Been a minute since he’s really looked at any of them.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: This is the old shit, man. I've done like fifteen albums since "Kind of Blue."

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah, but this is the stuff people dig. Miles chuckles gravely, signs two but stops on "Someday MPWC". Considers Frances on the cover. Dave can tell, thi woman really means something. Miles signs one more, holds out his hand. Justin gives hi his quarter of coke. Miles does a quick bump to test it, at Justin -

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right? - and pockets the coke. Justin holds out the empty money to Miles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Keep it. Miles tucks Frances under his arm.  35

dialogues.speaker: JUSTIN
dialogues.text: Uh... And exits out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles and Frances enter frame arm in arm in the cavernous main room of the dilapidated church. Dusty pews and scary judgemental angels, sun shines through the stained glass windows. Flamenco Sketches plays. Frances scans the room then slowly strides away from Mile down the center aisle, hands lightly touching the pews. A she passes, pirouetting, the ROOM CHANGES, darkness becom light (This effect will be achieved with a series of PHOT from a "locked off" camera position as the room is dresse ala City of God). The final PHOTO; Frances reaches the end of the room and turns back to face Miles. The scene comes to life, the sp transformed, an elegant stairway as its centerpiece, lead straight up to heaven. They both bound up the stairs into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles and Frances make love. Deep, passionate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frances and Miles lay on the bed having a lively conversation, laughing, sipping champagne. Frances is beautiful and Miles drinks her in...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: ...so, it's the same...

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (sly smile) Oh, it's the same, huh?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Yes. She floats her hand in the air. Miles reaches his up to m it. She holds her hand in a half finished flourish -  36

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know what I mean? When it's right there...and you hold it...and you don't breathe, and they don't breathe, and you're holding them...and then -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Whoosh... In a moment of inspiration, Fran hops up, wearing only Mi shirt, and begins to dance...

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: We fly... ..-Miles' visage slowly changes from rapt by her to rapt something else. As Miles watches, HER VOICE FADES out - we see he's in lo with her not only entirely, but it's every piece of Franc that he adores; hands, her legs, hair, eyes, etc. Miles focuses on each part, breaking her down, Picasso- esque...deconstructing Chopin -- WE NOW HEAR disparate notes, a chord, then another in the progression; half a tone up, birthing a composition based the nine note scale that bookends the composition, Gone, the sound-track to Frances’ dance. Fran spins, laughs, PU IN. Miles eyes narrow as he focuses on what's forming in mind. Fran spins, closes her eyes, given over to the rapture sh feels. When she opens them, Miles is gone. Fran smiles to herself, slightly high, knowing where he’s headed and tha she’s the elixir he drinks to create. She heads out the d seeing Miles at the bottom of the stairs - calls -

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sweetheart... Her voice faint, the chords on the SOUNDTRACK in control Miles keeps moving.

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Miles does a warm-up run on his horn as Frances enters. S calls to him but her voice is all but a whisper now. Mile cocks his head listening more closely to the chord, bring it forward in is mind as well as in the TRACK. He plays t it.  37 Fran watches, prideful. Miles finishes a phrase, half tur and catches sight of her. She puts on a little fake pout, “You left me alone.” Miles playfully pouts back, goes to

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Aww, baby girl... Miles kisses Frances softly, deeply. She kisses Miles bac walks backwards with him toward the couch, pulls him down drops down sitting next to her and after a moment, draws looking in her eyes. Miles, tasting her on his lips, rubs finger around his embouchure, closes his eyes, languidly blows Fran's softness into the horn. Then Miles' attention is drawn to the sound of... is that Funkadelic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles and Dave pull up to the curb. Miles takes the stash coke and his gun out of the secret compartment, seems som effected by the Frances moment we've just witnessed. Mile hops out, pops his hip back in place as Dave arrives on t sidewalk next to him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Jesus... Miles holds his hand out to Dave.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Keys. Dave plops the keys into his hand. Miles heads to the doo taking the Jag key off the ring, Dave following.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell you what; gas me up, get it washed and then go grab me some catfish.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (beat) Cat- Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You got a problem with that? Dave sighs, test two, I guess. He’ll grin and bear it... until he can get those tapes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure —  38 Dave holds out his hand for the key but then they both co their heads to the door. (Miles Davis ?) Music on, people voices. Miles and Dave exchange a look, then Miles turns knob, pushes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles is stunned. There's a party in full swing; FUNK MUS blasting on the stereo. 40 PEOPLE, black, white, shady, musicians, drug addicts, kind of people who party in your house when you're gone. Dieter, who got out of the cab earlier with Janice, is th first to spot Miles, pokes Janice, points. They work thei way over to get to Miles. Dave is waiting for Miles to blow up, as other guests gre him like a famous stranger in his own house. Janice, zoom a little, puts her arms around Miles -

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Hey, baby, you didn’t hear me calling - ?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What the fuck is going on, Janice?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: It’s Tuesday?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: So what?!

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Don’t you remember? You said we could party over here Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I ain’t talked to you in forever. When I say that?

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: You know, like... weeks ago. Miles makes his way over to the reel to reel machine, Jan in lockstep with him.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You always pulling some shit - How'd you get in anyway?  39

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Remember? That key you hid from me that time? Miles pushes a couple stoned people away whose tipsy drin threaten to spill on the machine - and his tape...

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Move, muthafuckas - Dieter jams up to Miles while he hurriedly fast forwards tape, removes it from the machine. Dave notes it, moves i behind him, staying close to his prey. As Miles puts his away, Dieter rambles on:

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: Miiiiiiiles Daaaaaaaaviiiiiis. Good to see you again, my man. Dieter holds out his hand for a shake, Miles doesn’t even notice. You know, you are so far out the way you just stopped making music because you decide when you live and die, the artist is God... Miles gets the tape in it's can, stuffs it into a drawer few gawkers pass here and there, clocking Miles “Shit, th him... etc.” Miles struggles with the sticking drawer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Let me help you, man... Dave helps Miles find the slide, constantly clocking the tape, it’s date, trying not to be obvious.

dialogues.speaker: DIETER
dialogues.text: And when you're dead, you will be bigger than ever, and you should burn your body in the Ganges River, the holiest water -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Get the fuck off me, Hitler.

dialogues.speaker: HITLER
dialogues.text: Miles finally gets the drawer shut.  40

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Dieter, cool it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah, man. Back up! Dave playing bodyguard now as Miles locks the drawer with of the keys on his ring, Dave clocking it all. Miles scoo up Frances and turns to Janice.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Get all these muthafucka’s outta -

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: (quick) Please, Miles. You promised me. And I straightened up and everything. Look, I’‘1l tell everybody to leave you alone, and we won’t go too late, ok? Please... Beat. Miles stares at her, holding on to Frances. He poin to his reel to reel.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Keep your simple-ass friends away from my shit.

dialogues.speaker: JANICE
dialogues.text: Of course, baby.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: And stay the fuck out the basement. Janice turns pushing Dieter off. Miles heads toward the door leading downstairs, flips thr the keys.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Want me to stay up here, keep an eye on things? Miles opens the basement door with his key.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: C'mon. ANGLE DAVE: Dave glances at the tape, follows Miles THROU THE DOOR. As the door closes behind them, glimpse the saloon doors opening and Harper, Walter, and Junior enter. Junior has trumpet case in hand.  41

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Told you.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Yes, you did. Kudos to your sources.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: I don't know about this, man.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: You don't need to know - I know. You just do your thing.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: We're just gonna walk right up on him in the middle of a party? Harper puts an arm around Junior.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: You know who John Coltrane was before he was John Coltrane? A bar walker. He literally walked across the bar playing his horn, people throwing nickels at him. Then Miles hears him play - (Harper mimes a plane taking off) Whoosh...! “John Coltrane”. You think you're worse than a bar walker? Trust me. We'll find a little corner, you'll play and that'll be it.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: (wary ) Yeah, he didn’t look too much like he wanted to -

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Junior, stop playing with your pussy, alright! This is 'take a shot' time.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: (low, looking away) Fuck you, Harper... Harper smiles. Junior is just like he likes him; edgy. Re to blow.  42

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Miles and Dave enter Miles' sanctuary; a State of the art studio. The Sorcerer's Cave.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (muttering) India... muthafuckas are crazy.. A trumpet on a stand, an electric piano, drums. His Gramm on a shelf, one is used as a doorstop - his gold and plat albums line the walls, boxing photos of Sugar Ray, Jack Johnson, Joe Louis, and of Miles sparring in the ring. A heavy bag hangs from the ceiling. Dave looks around, impressed, realizing he's inside Miles' brain.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Okay. Cool... You record a lot down here?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Yeah, sometimes... Miles puts the "...Prince..." record down, dumps some cok Frances and cuts some rails. She looks at him disapprovin

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what...?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Man, she's beautiful. That look in her eye, that's something.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Umhm.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Frances, right? Miles shoots Dave a quick look then both men's attention drawn to the door upstairs and the jiggling of the knob. Miles shakes his head, tears off a piece of staff paper covered in his scrawl of musical notes, rolls it up and snorts a line. Holds it out for Dave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm good. Miles shrugs - suit yourself, starts to put it to the sid

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh...  43 Dave reconsiders, reaches for it. Miles hands it over and Dave does a rail -

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, man... Holy fuck, man. Fuck- fuck -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Yeah, Tuesday, like a motherfucker. Dave sits, stands, sits, shakes his head, really playing up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You gonna make it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I'm gonna need a drink, man, or a, or a Valium, or a Quaalude, or a brick... Miles chuckles at his jester, shares the laugh with Franc veiled in dope like lace, twinkling back at him. Miles reaches to the side, pulls a couple Heinekins out of a MI FRIDGE.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Uh, I was thinking something a little stronger, you know. One of those drinks upstairs. You mind? Points up. Beat. Then Miles smirks.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Go head. Miles tosses Dave the ring of keys -

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lock it behind you. Little silver one. And grab me some of that brown.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Cool. Good. Yeah. Dave exits with the “keys to the kingdom”. Miles looks at trumpet - it looks at him - he wanders over to the heavy starts jabbing it. POP-POP-POP - musically rhythmic - something stirs in him, eyes pass over Frances without looking at her, to the piano.  44

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave locks the basement door behind him, his gaze drawn t the reel to reel table and the drawer holding the tape.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Dave Braden, you are so bloody good... He makes a beeline for the it. Arriving at the table Dave looks for something to conceal tape in, spies Miles' valise on a shelf next to the cabin papers brimming over - that’ll do. He tags the small key the ring and shoves it into the lock, opens the cabinet drawer - double checks the label on the tape, the date (PUSH) - Bingo.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hello... He pockets the keys - his wheels spin for a hot second, a defining moment: “Am I a thief, or am I a journalist...?”

dialogues.speaker: HARPER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Rolling Stone... Dave casually drops the valise and hip closes the cabinet drawer (but it sticks and doesn’t close all the way) as h turns to find Harper pushing through people to get over t him, Junior trailing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: How'd you weasel your way back in?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (a little pointed) Waltzed right in with the rest of the riff raff.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Lucky you. Where's Miles?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: No idea.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: So what are you doing here?  45

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: I'm a writer, man. Kinda what we do. Walter walks up as Dave grabs a bottle of brown LIQUOR of nearby table.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Chick over there said Miles was with him.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: I heard that too.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: He was. He left.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Left his own party.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (indicating the room) It's his house. It ain't his party. People just...show up. Harper looks at Walter, chuckles, pointing to Dave, "get load of this asshole."

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (cops to it) Yeah, it's kinda fucked, huh? My understanding, happens a lot. Dave takes a pull on the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Help yourself. He takes another swig.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: It's not yours, the fuck you care? Insulted, Harper cocks his head at this creature who for strange reason wants to be abused now. Walter steps aroun oblige. Dave takes a slight step back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: OK, relax... take it easy, man. Hey, you mind if I ask you a few questions?

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: ...the fuck outta here...  46 Dave backs away.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: And he continues, undeterred by enmity and rancorous spite, fixed on his prize, his bow string, taut... Dave turns, and folds into the party.

dialogues.speaker: WALTER
dialogues.text: Fucking clown. Harper turns to speak to Junior, Dave takes the opportuni to quickly unlock the basement door and rush inside.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: This is what I'm talking about, kid. Don't let this be your future, okay - bunch of degenerates partying in your house and you ain't even home.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Yeah... When Harper looks up, Dave's gone. Junior is drawn to the reel to reel machine, intrigued by what incredible music might have spun through these wheels.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: Walter, go get the car. Junior touches the machine with reverence, then happens t peek down into the exposed drawer below. His eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: JUNIOR
dialogues.text: Whoa... Harper clocks Junior, walks over and has a peek for himse A Cheshire cat grin spreads over Harper's lips.

dialogues.speaker: HARPER
dialogues.text: (to himself) Fucking Rolling Stone...

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Dave opens the door hearing Miles playing the piano (Chop cum Gone), composing on the fly. Miles jots down some scribble on ledger paper then speaks without looking up.  47

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What took you so long?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (ala Dieter) Miiiiiilllles DAAAVIIIS!

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: He got you too, huh? Dave nods, holds the liquor out to Miles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We drink out of glasses here, muthafucka?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Of course. I don't know what I was... Be right back. Dave happily starts to head back up.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Give it here.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You sure? Miles' answer is his extended hand. Dave's gonna be here a minute.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay. Miles takes the bottle, throws back a swig.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So... that was beautiful, man. I didn't know you played piano. Miles takes another swig, goes back to playing the piano.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: This ain't playing. Playing around, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Sounds good to me. (beat) So you studied piano too, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Just woke up black and knew how to play.  48

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: You're black? Miles chuckles. Dave smiles. They're starting to ease int it. Dave picks up boxing gloves, casually checks out the and tear, ponders their history.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Frances loves Chopin...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (off record cover) Yeah... She looks...very classy, you know. Refined Kinda mischievous too?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (on is own beam) Stravinsky, Bartok, Chopin... studied all those cats, man. They broke convention, you know. Pushing back at that... standard, classical bag... Bird and Diz was doing that on stage every night, on the fly. Didn't write it down. Just came out of 'em. Shit was scary. I wanted to quit every night. Dave slips on the gloves, really starts tuning Miles in.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The old people come up to me and ask, “Why don't you play the way you used to?' I say to them, 'Tell me how I used to.'" You have to play a long time to be able to play like yourself. Man, don't do nothing like you used to. It don't move, then that's dead music. It's dead. Miles stops playing. Doesn't move. Neither does Dave. A weighted moment.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: So is it...fair to say that Miles turns to Dave, narrows his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Your turn, muthafucka.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: My turn what? Miles gestures; “Give it up.” Dave smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, you want the Dave Braden story, huh? Okay... I was born in Scotland, grew up, wrote some shit, did some other stuff, then I came to your house. Miles smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You forgot something. Who socked you up?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: (smirks ) You going senile?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Before me. Dave sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave standing near a car arguing with someone unseen.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) My wife's cock-sucker boyfriend - He turns, responding to a voice and gets sucker-punched, the pavement. RALPH, 35, a big ape, starts rummaging thro his pockets. DAVE (V.O. CONT’D) - thought it was his job to collect twenty-dollars and fifty cents of fucking alimony. Dave's POV: A beautiful woman, SUSIE, 32, in a parked car the curb, looking down at him. She mouths, "I love you... Ralph takes Dave's money and they drive off...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Then I came to your house.  50 Dave does a small bow. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Alimony.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: So ex-wife...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Says it almost misty though.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: (beat) You really miss her, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah. Miles giggles, gets up from the piano.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Man, throw a punch. Dave is dumbstruck for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come on... Miles goes to the bag, holds it. Dave throws an easy punc

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now throw a real one. Dave looks at him, hits the bag hard, moves Miles back a Miles recovers, winces, his hip. Dave doesn't see, or car Miles plays it off.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hold the bag. Dave holds the bag for Miles.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Naw, you don't lock down chicks like that, man... Miles hits the bag.  51

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Punch comes from the hip, right. Hip. Miles hits the bag again then holds the bag for Dave braces. Dave throws a hard punch. Miles absorbs, returns bag for Dave to hold.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Turn your wrist over, snap it. Miles keeps punching - fuck the pain - like the pain - ne the pain -

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Wives are for kids, and serious shit. You don't mess with that. (beat, mutters a rare admission) Yeah, I coulda done that better...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: What? Miles shakes his head - nothing. He steps into his PUNCH

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The horns on the track Gone from Gil and Miles Porgy and Bess, blare out strong. Miles in the booth drops hard ont the couch, making a phone call.

dialogues.speaker: TEO
dialogues.text: Let’s get another one, Gil. TWO SEXY GIRLS are perched next on the couch too, looking Miles like he's the daily special. In the studio, musicia play. The European ring is replaced.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Savoy Hotel, London.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Frances Taylor. Room 516.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Davis. One moment. Miles listens, waits. PLAYBACK streams over the speakers, opening passage of "GONE". A bit of a mess. Then -  52

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, Mr. Davis, there doesn't seem to be an answer. Would you like to leave another -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: You muthafuckas know how to slip a note under a door? Miles hangs up. He takes a long drag on his cigarette and exhales, his countenance clouded, finally focusing on the girls on the couch for a beat, saying nothing. He takes another drag, stubs out his cigarette. Walks back into th studio, interrupting the take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Philly Joe Jones, Paul Chambers and a 12 PIECE GROUP, conducted by Gil Evans, are working through "Gone" from "Porgy and Bess". Gil Evans, his face a cipher, stops the group... again.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: (waving his hand) Alright, alright... The musicians groan.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Timing’s all messed up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I played my nine in perfect time.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: That's the problem, man. Everybody ain't playin’ the chart like it's written, at least be musical about it.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE ROYAL
dialogues.text: Man, this is some tricky shit.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: So what? Be wrong strong. Otherwise lay out. Teo, can you hear the Jerome and Phil? In a SERIES OF CUTS we see Miles genius as he rearranges players, maximizing the acoustics, changes a note or two the woodwind section, confers with Gil, etc. Then -  53 cuT: A light an airy moment - a break in playing...

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yeah, we were all up in that shit like a muthfucka. Cleaner than a broke dick dog.

dialogues.speaker: ERNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah that suit was somethin’ else.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Yeah, Prez turned me on to that cat.

dialogues.speaker: GIL
dialogues.text: Okay, let's take it from the head.

dialogues.speaker: ENGINEER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: "Gone" take fourteen. They play again, fumbling to the same result. Before Gil stop them, Miles plays his solo, his eyes daring anybody cut his wisdom. The group powers through the song...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RINGING. Miles is in a silk robe, in a chair in the maste bedroom, slumped back, looking bored. He answers the phon as we begin to DOLLY around him.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Hey? I've been calling you all damn day.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Honey, it's 6:30 in the morning here. I just woke -

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Oh... Okay... I just uh... Okay... Miles puts his finger to his lips, "Shhhh...", turns away  54

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Guess what, baby. We're a royal hit! We got extended. Three more weeks.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I want you to come home, Frances.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (beat) Honey, did you hear what I just said -- I can't.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Just come home. Come home for two days. Frances says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: MILES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They can get by without you for two or three damn days. INTERCUT FRANCES in ECU sitting on the edge of the bed in room at the SAVOY HOTEL, looking beautiful at 6:30am, lik some women do.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: Baby... The TWO HOT GIRLS we met at the recording studio are nake bed stifling giggles, silently gesturing Miles to join th A Polaroid camera with a bunch of Polaroid photos of the three of them in various combinations, fucking, are strew about.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: It's because I didn't marry you?

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about it, it's a good thing, we should do that. Let's have a real serious talk about it when you get here.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, can you hold on a second, baby?  55 Frances takes the receiver away from her ear, covers the mouthpiece. Beat. Then puts the phone back to her ear and just listens. On the other end of the line Miles’ agitation starts to slowly mount.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Fran...? Frances... Frances finally speaks.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES
dialogues.text: I’m back.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: I'm having a plane pick you up tomorrow. (beat) Okay? (beat) I need you.

dialogues.speaker: FRANCES, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I'll... work it out with my understudy... he scans his surroundings but no there’s no Miles. Dave thinks about the night, smiles to himself, grabs some ledger paper of the piano, starts furiously composing his thoughts, flowing, getting some good shit down. But then, CRASH. Upstairs Miles is cursing, thrashing abo in a panic...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles finally jerks the reel to reel cabinet drawer all t way open - tape is definitely not there - he rifles throu the debris around the machine - zip. Dave enters the spac sees Miles who whips around to him.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Somebody stole my fucking music! Dave's face goes slack. This ain’t good.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Oh, man. Those assholes... Shit!  56

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Shit, what?! What assholes?!

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: That Harper guy from Columbia, and that kid were here.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: Here last night?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: MILES
dialogues.text: ...the fuck you didn't you tell me that last night?

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
